8EEB84C9EC344AFA942653526F09AB6E.description: Compare observations and data with others.

72D13360791C43F6B760D348FD4CE0B9.description: Collaborate to combine recorded data into a single list or chart.

4C7F5B021FD543FEB7E0A56D63EBDF7D.description: Determine if observations relate to the purpose of the investigation.

FA5D9A14065F4560BFA8A098F04C2EE1.description: Develop questions for the purpose of an investigation.

F7FE8554E34B4D12B4418FE65480DE21.description: Explore various purposes for conducting an investigation.

09029E2F48004B419230694308B50A06.description: Investigations involve carrying out procedures for a purpose.

80720052F3FF4D668375B6E40E87C441.description: Data collected by people performing the same investigation can be combined.

8F2143D376A84CDAB7945542448B374C.description: Repetition of an investigation includes performing the same procedures in the same way.

3913BEC5CCCE41099D1F160AF0290FF6.description: Observations and data should be similar if the investigation is repeated.

82616BEA61994EBC810C484979848435.description: Data should relate to the purpose of an investigation.

369116E7D127435BB2AD9B9FA93DAFB7.description: Procedures scientists use to guide investigations include asking questions, making predictions, planning the investigation, observing and recording data, analyzing data, reaching conclusions and discussing observations and conclusions

54C7FBA4F67B4AE0BE05D768EF8BDA64.description: Investigations are conducted for purposes such as  answering questions, building knowledge, satisfying curiosity and problem solving

216FE3D85BA74B1EAB0FEBA276EE5610.description: Students examine investigation and explain how it is influenced by purpose.

FDF9B25621C24795BC7633741B66EF41.description: Scientific Methods: Investigation of the physical world is enhanced through the use of scientific methods that attempt to remove human biases and increase objectivity.

F483433840154A3F8F2F21C7850E14A6.description: Exchange ideas to design clear three- to four-step instructions, including repetition, to achieve a desired outcome.

E43D969A917F4691A971DA8280CDDE37.description: Describe a situation in which repetition simplifies instructions.

61CC34452DCD43148C25BB3EF7A339AE.description: Debug any errors in a set of instructions to achieve a desired outcome.

5593F47742204707A606050124A5F18E.description: Test instructions with three to four steps to verify that a desired outcome is achieved.

770C900B265D4B5783A42CAABAD83E96.description: Refine instructions to more efficiently achieve a desired outcome.

B664CD9F10AD432B8EF7BC542E69F106.description: Predict the outcome of instructions that have three to four steps.

0EAFE4FCD8FF425BA9FAC58B197214ED.description: Create three-step to four-step instructions that achieve a desired outcome.

4917B83294FC440A92D553E36C3B2A22.description: Work individually or in groups to create instructions using precise words, pictures, or diagrams.

588D84A9438A4C76A7649C836A16245C.description: Identify ways creativity is used to design instructions.

C43D6B8262AA45AD86F6504F9B09EDC8.description: Instructions may be simplified by repeating steps.

2A0F0D8A9EA8420EA9765B9EB0C4DA0C.description: Instructions can be created to be precise, reliable, and efficient to achieve the desired outcome.

76B65CE801354505AD55816888CBCD01.description: Instructions are designed using creativity and problem solving, which can be enhanced through collaboration.

392B3D0CA5144C5794858BB10AE2DDF9.description: Many daily activities include repeated steps, such as  brushing teeth  and tying one shoe and then using the same process on the other shoe

01D09072143F4BDAA1A8A6391F9834B6.description: Debugging can increase the reliability of instructions.

A66F9A948CAD483E9AFFA4FEB5573C58.description: Debugging is the process of identifying and removing errors in a set of instructions to achieve a desired outcome.

71B4284D4ED44B639D26DF37FC2898C1.description: Many activities at school and in the workplace require creativity and collaboration to improve ideas.

49DD35C9664E452EB01AD280D1A0C883.description: Many people, individually or in groups, can create instructions, such as teachers, parents, students and computer programmers

2CF413445D9045F981D8EAB9D7AB079D.description: The reliability and efficiency of instructions can be affected by how they are communicated, including form; e.g., verbal, visual, written, order and clarity

A461C9EF43FB487E932D82E9777B41AE.description: Efficiency of instructions refers to designing in a way that yields desired outcomes with the least amount of energy, time, or steps.

05FE775C1E994DBD921E7FF02DE7CEC1.description: Reliability of instructions means they consistently lead to the same desired outcome.

30C2E8C3858345B08518647BCD389559.description: Precise instructions have a variety of components, includingverbs, simple language, clear steps and a starting and stopping point

0C3436C674924650A3BB0EEDF1DBE83C.description: Collaboration can result in improved ideas, which may enhance creativity and problem solving.

1E85191D276F4D95AC17B8C914CD2D32.description: Creativity can be used to design instructions for games, sports, investigations, recipes and computer programs

400BC8B3553E4EACA0E33D1B5D9CD37F.description: Creativity is the ability to generate something original, such as  ideas, technology, tools and products

66F1321890F14CDF84D17C2254BA5E5B.description: Students apply creativity when designing instructions to achieve a desired outcome.

EB41AB4ED3354645BC52F8B4FF390803.description: Computer Science: Problem solving and scientific inquiry are developed through the knowledgeable application of creativity, design, and computational thinking.

5385E895C0324971948D1886909C644C.description: Identify ways in which people show care for land, plants, and animals through cultural practices.

BCA771FB02B4462DB33A3E3B7A0747B4.description: Discuss how humans might interact with land, plants, and animals if they see land, plants, and animals as equals.

B1761571A2414D21BA49B9B7FA658472.description: Discuss and compare life cycles of various plants and animals.

F44ED9590C2D426CB279D8E8D220A605.description: Represent the life cycles of various plants and animals.

3267B5056DC840E99893AFDA654B8E60.description: Identify similarities between offspring and their parents.

A3C879BA3F2A4C76BDBE3A769F379E2C.description: Explain positive and negative impacts of human behaviour on plants and animals.

EEE340C047ED42688E264F5BD620B02B.description: Discuss ways to respect plants and animals while interacting in various environments.

E205AD9DBAFB4E668C02F89EBB0C3BA3.description: The ways in which individuals or groups relate to land, plants, and animals can influence cultural practices.

26BA62C9AEE04E2986753BB0ACA74711.description: Plants and animals have observable patterns or stages in their development.

A312B0351EB3483392C07B0ED38B41D2.description: Plants and animals share similarities with their offspring.

3207A39680B04AD186A715777F05771D.description: Plants and animals can be affected by human behaviour.

A54406841E764279B4BDB08C969D563F.description: Care and consideration for land, plants, and animals can be demonstrated through cultural practices, such as taking only what is needed, using the whole plant or animal, protecting water and soil and treating land, plants, and animals as relatives

EB5BF730871D4B8384158C57E63DE7D1.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit relate to land, plants, and animals as equals.

3081EF88312747BDB5F3933F23A4AF7A.description: Life cycles can be represented in many ways, such as illustrations, diagrams, models and stories

AE0B54C4F5734CE1ADE3FCE128601006.description: A life cycle shows the different stages of life that a plant or an animal goes through

7A732FAD04DB46E6AC7A2D69B4432F01.description: Offspring are the children of plants or animals.

0F953BD0658145D39AC59BC7E6DDD2ED.description: Some human behaviours can negatively affect plants and animals, such as  littering, polluting, using up materials from nature that plants and animals need to live and introducing plants and other animals that are not native to the area

129EBF6ED80A4E5FA50B11B92B40CAE7.description: Some human behaviours can positively affect plants and animals, such as  reducing, reusing, recycling, and repurposing, recovering natural areas, protecting natural spaces and creating parks

FF4F955AC2C34B7DB199FC9F36FE7889.description: Students investigate the growth and development of plants and animals and consider their relationship to humans.

2A669C176480442DA34DF05F1674C656.description: Living Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

E256B8762E204625AFDC30996DF9D9CA.description: Represent ways that Earth’s rotation connects to patterns of day and night.

72AA1E8C0A3A4F98862CD9158A4FA7F7.description: Describe the relationship between time and Earth revolving around the Sun.

D10AB2D7E27C478D838F6D5D9FC29890.description: Identify bodies of water on Earth that contain salt water.

69EA6A3444A34FE2A067B25B2CA67B0B.description: Identify bodies of water on Earth that contain fresh water.

C657AC6351B84B1A9D0D4C205C4620E8.description: Create a model to represent various types of landforms and bodies of water.

6CB38880F6BC4A3C8417C7B509333F96.description: Diagram the flow of water from small creeks to an ocean.

CAD0D5679433498F833729D6FD4BDD82.description: Investigate local and provincial bodies of water.

AAED7E14F22E4DEB8165D3293C2DBA93.description: Identify and discuss UNESCO World Heritage Sites found in Alberta.

C3A6E37054A044EEBB12513BBE08E811.description: Compare various landforms on Earth’s surface.

DFBAE3E2D2234C43967B29D0C036A2A4.description: Identify landforms that are found locally or in Alberta.

E29AE59D9F424EFDB5CF196B799DB10D.description: Discuss how the various components of Earth interact to support life.

2EC4610C1DA34E7E801CEFC29E6D7869.description: Earth revolves around the Sun and rotates.

7BBC915EB7D040018DED880F75FCAB56.description: Earth’s surface is mostly covered by bodies of water.

A433037BF7F54157A05EE6A6566FC945.description: Earth’s surface consists of various types of landforms.

03EB13336E5741DA831F9DDE79F11671.description: Earth consists of many components that support life.

D4C3C6F71B2D453DAB9FC7915AFB7303.description: Earth’s surface experiences day when it faces the Sun, and night when it does not face the Sun.

30E2B9DBE08A431CBAD8BCA121DE7DD1.description: A day is the length of time it takes Earth to rotate fully (on its axis).

3EC74B782C094ADFA9E6843B9CA91E17.description: A year is the length of time it takes Earth to revolve around the Sun.

F757B4D560AC4E7AB83BE198F962C142.description: Saltwater bodies include oceans and seas.

0CAD6D8FF80B438E87FADD201DDDC0F9.description: Freshwater bodies include glaciers, most lakes, wetlands and rivers

C95117B2735B4380B52DEFA2A03BCD04.description: Water found on Earth can be either fresh or salt water.

124F3F9C0CC54E8580892ED0DE9AF961.description: Water flows downhill from smaller bodies of water to larger bodies of water in the following ways: small creeks flowing downhill and merging to form small streams, small streams merging to form larger streams and rivers, streams and small rivers merging to form larger rivers and large rivers merging into major waterways, such as oceans

A473E4137B2245FF88430549A656C389.description: Bodies of water on Earth’s surface include oceans, glaciers, lakes, wetlands and rivers

F836C865B6814573BDA5B4655DEC71EE.description: Some places and landforms in Alberta have been identified as UNESCO World Heritage Sites, such as Dinosaur Provincial Park, Wood Buffalo National Park and Head-Smashed-In Buffalo Jump

0DD4E002442D4FE19BD129E684A18671.description: Landforms can be described as hilly, rocky, steep or flat and big or small

B4A3FE4016AB4768B5D66498A0DC0C9E.description: Alberta has many different landforms, such as plateaus, mountains, valleys, hills and prairies

C7110975B0CA4EF0A81F20E901AEFFF0.description: A landform is a natural feature of Earth’s surface.

7DB9358C241A4A51BCC1D2CFCC75140E.description: Scientists are looking for life on other planets and moons.

D3E8796C950E47059E220AA09C8185D3.description: At this time, Earth is the only planet known to support life.

83A4F8E4539A4B248F43FFC14AADBCDC.description: Components of Earth include land, water, air and plants, humans, and other animals

E0CCB6BD67FB413F92A9B6C17F0E3CDD.description: Students investigate Earth, its landforms, its bodies of water, and its relationship to the Sun.

908A5E21E1B34C90A55CF71236432809.description: Earth Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

47EFC0B849F04E56A60AD6AC3E37FF71.description: Examine how natural objects affect the path of sunlight.

83DE7F30CA914BAC835D8685846454A2.description: Conduct an investigation to determine how the path of light can be affected.

A5245B472CF14ACAADD80BC8CEB8EFBD.description: Build a device to change the behaviour of sound.

521EB0D9B3414A3D93D6A6FB4BABADC2.description: Safely explore the production and behaviour of sound.

C1C79D6D5FD6485C82AAA06C87FC8692.description: Listen to sounds and describe their characteristics.

C3EE052EE5724C458192C83DACA070D3.description: Relate vibration to the production of sound.

1DF91E63F2E94896AEE06A19958D7E75.description: Behaviours of light affect its path.

584A73F498064E19AA06FF9B67038E90.description: Behaviours of sound affect its characteristics.

44CA9A1CC706408DB643521F513B2A53.description: The path of sunlight can be affected in a variety of ways by natural objects, such as leaves, trees, bodies of water and mountains

15A04A2D21DD4DA0B242B90272CCA6F5.description: The path of light is affected by mirrors, prisms, and water.

7E98CB857DD849D19431B3E2643494DD.description: Light travels through objects that can be seen through (transparent).

1D9657F8764B4ECDBB82618B78AD15E4.description: Light behaves in various ways, including travelling in a straight line from its source, bouncing off a surface (reflection), bending as it travels from one material to another (refraction) and splitting into colours (dispersion)

DD6C7A491AFA4812AB03B3352DC35D15.description: Sources of light include the Sun, electricity, fire and some plants and animals (bioluminescence)

B68A08ECC2C849A1BCA276981A5A3D18.description: Properties of materials that affect the production and behaviour of sound include size, texture, shape and type

A462A78341494B0BB5C6427DDC7580E1.description: Sound can travel through air, water, and some solids.

E8EBFEB0272748DF824A4FCC07577A11.description: Characteristics of sound include volume, which can be described as quiet or loud, pitch, which can be described as high or low and duration, which can be described as short or long

6283577B02C94FDFA4D136FF839170E4.description: Sources of sound can be natural or human-made, such as musical instruments, speakers and headphones, vocal cords of humans and other animals and objects hitting each other

4C3EF6393AB341368FF2BF6F5FACF09B.description: Vibration is a rapid back-and-forth movement.

086387919EB041E79DFB4782AD394BC1.description: Sound is produced by vibrations of objects.

A2874B08046A4E09B4E83E6032F10001.description: Sound behaves in various ways, including travelling in a straight line from its source transferring from one object to another bouncing off a surface (reflection/diffusion) stopping in an object (absorption)

1D4BB989B36E4942AC1391AB251A9954.description: Students investigate the behaviours of light and sound.

B7DC95CB515F4997BACCB05087673D05.description: Energy: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.

8BA0DA4ADE914CE6AF2D1BACD4A97488.description: Discuss the choice of material based on availability and purpose.

3C6A607DF4D24C0A836CB05E0F1C28DC.description: Select a material and use it to create an item for a specific purpose.

F65783CE260343D59F55D20C0570F85E.description: Explain the relationship between suitability of materials and purpose.

0819C9F30AEC49969182CAD0B24F014A.description: Compare the properties of materials to determine what material is best suited for a specific purpose.

2D8FFDCF423942E4A1D07A95948A5699.description: Identify natural materials used by local First Nations, Métis, or Inuit and relate the materials’ uses to specific purposes.

80DAF03CDFD34FFB89F7AAE5800A8ACC.description: Identify an object that can be made from different materials.

421CEFDF3DD44DF68D4E8F52E14CDE0E.description: Identify natural and processed materials that could be used for a specific purpose.

80731A22CD764DA6ADF0CFAA8D55DF33.description: Sort various materials as being natural or processed.

E23ABEFAC38E42C8911D8D5899CB944F.description: Measure various materials using non-standard measurements.

CCC6DA2A04D44E12B6237BDA84F1759C.description: Combine materials to create an object for a specific purpose.

9984050D8F724CE387ADE7E4151E03F7.description: Identify the materials used to make various objects.

833B72E4D0004388B4239359EF54D565.description: Some materials are more suitable than others for making a product for a specific purpose.

E5F15E1882324D39886004DC453E341D.description: The purpose of an object influences the choice of materials used to produce it.

B9E7D811860249E898D7CA19DC5B50FD.description: Natural and processed materials are used to make objects that serve a variety of purposes.

0CB6991F363245B2A3FA4D425EEF7AB6.description: All processed materials originate from natural materials.

8B2CDBFA486D44D6A520A4B2573A0E1B.description: Materials can be combined in a variety of ways to make objects.

730A9FFE35ED4F84824DFDC696584E93.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit use of materials is informed by  traditional knowledge time of year, availability, taking only what is needed and respect for the land

8EF238A429534B64B16FBEC617B617AC.description: Knowledge of the properties of materials and their purposes is important in many occupations and roles, such as carpenter, engineer, designer and Knowledge Keeper or Elder

994E61ED1E624219A630134AC263A84C.description: Examples of objects made from natural materials that are created and used by First Nations, Métis, and Inuit are Dene birchbark baskets, travois, Red River carts, canoes and Inuit scraping tools; e.g., ulu

858D6F5784374BA8A115E2E576DA6DF8.description: An object can be made from different materials; e.g., a canoe can be made from wood or aluminium.

DDAF12DBEA0C4CE8B7F07D0021B86C42.description: Processed materials are made by humans.

EC567CFA9DEB4D9FA8CBEF5F95818729.description: Natural materials are those that come from plants, animals, the land, or the sky.

CAB5CE4F419A4495A3CAD215D4FC2C9E.description: Various properties of materials can be measured, including length and weight (mass).

98BE57F0314C41FA88B83C04CBA0E4A4.description: Properties of materials that can be tested include if light passes through (transparency), if water is absorbed, if the material can be shaped (malleability), if light is reflected (reflection)

DD21D95B00BF41E899E159092D331100.description: Materials are used to make objects.

F7B0D49DD22D4DCCA3A8FB2417E2EB94.description: Students investigate properties of materials and relate them to a purpose.

98EECC96F2924257B9FF0684A66B5CB7.description: Matter: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.
